intro: Lasiacis ruscifolia var. ruscifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leaved broomrape, is a parasitic plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies on host plants for nutrients. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its leafless stems and yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid regions, often attaching itself to various host species such as shrubs or grasses. Its unique botanical structure allows it to thrive without photosynthesis, making it an interesting subject in ecological studies. Due to its parasitic nature, it can have significant impacts on the growth and health of its host plants.
